channel.description: Hey guys! item.title: Any tips for differentiating verses?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
The term ‘bridge’ is used to mean various things.

It can sometimes refer to the ‘pre-chorus’, which is a change in tone between verse and chorus that’s used to create momentum towards the chorus.

More commonly, it refers to a mood shift, often used after the second chorus, in place of a third verse and pre-chorus.
It often involves a significant drop in energy, a bit of breathing space, and is (commonly) immediately followed by the third chorus, which is typically the peak energy within a common song structure.

It’s rare to have a bridge followed by the wind-down/outro, as it’s often used to set up some contrast ahead of a big third chorus.

item.title: Any tips for differentiating verses?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Will it be a vocal track?
(You say ‘verse’ and ‘song’ which suggests yes, but say ‘drop’, rather than ‘chorus’, which suggests possibly not.)

If it is a vocal track, then don’t forget you’ll also have vocal layers available to change things up between sections.

Will it have a full lyric or just a simple, repeating refrain?

Resist the temptation to make a complete instrumental track and simply stack vocals on top*. Best to leave space for the vocals, including vocal effects and layering.

(* Although that approach is quite common for ‘dance music’ tracks which have a simple, repeating vocal refrain, compared to full songs.)

If it is a vocal track, try to track down instrumental versions of good reference songs.
It’ll give you a good set of references of how it’s usually handled within a vocal track.

(I recently checked out instrumental versions of the last two Purity Ring albums. Much less going on than you might expect.)

item.title: Any tips for differentiating verses?
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
There’s a lot you can do and of course you can mix and match all these things to taste:

Keep some of thefoundational elements of the first verse (chords, bass, drums, whatever) and then do new melodies and/or everything else

Keep all the same stuff, but with different sounds

Keep everything but change the drums up

Make it a stripped down version of the first verse, perhaps something in the background of the first verse is now the focus

Have the same ideas going, but with different rhythms. For example verse one melody is primarily an 8th note feel. So verse two could be that same melody but with a 16th note feel, or whatever.

Or you could always just write a completely new verse. Something that keeps the energy moving forward, but different. You can still have your chorus/drop come in when expected to keep a sense of familiarity.

My favorites are the last two, but I do a little bit of all these things
